title.rendered: What is TypeScript?

content.rendered:
• TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript. It is an object-oriented and tightly typed programming language. TypeScript code is transformed to JavaScript, which may be used in any environment that supports JavaScript, including browsers, Node.js, and your own applications.
  • Anders Hejlsberg of MICROSOFT created TypeScript. TypeScript was created in response to the limitations of JavaScript for constructing large-scale applications within Microsoft and among its external customers. There was a demand for bespoke tooling to make developing JavaScript components easier due to the complexity of working with complicated JavaScript code.
  • TypeScript is a variant of JavaScript with a few more features. TypeScript extends JavaScript with extra syntax to provide a more robust interface with your editor. TypeScript is a scripting language that is compatible with JavaScript and relies on type inference to deliver advanced functionality without the need for additional code.

excerpt.rendered: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript. It is an object-oriented and tightly typed programming language. TypeScript code is transformed to JavaScript, which may be used in any environment that supports JavaScript, including browsers, Node.js, and your own applications. Anders Hejlsberg of MICROSOFT created TypeScript. TypeScript was created in response to the limitations of JavaScript for constructing large-scale applications […]

title.rendered: Explain Arrays in TypeScript

content.rendered:
A collection of values of the same data type is called an array. It’s a kind that’s been defined by the user. To store values of the same kind, you use arrays. Arrays are collections of values that are ordered and indexed. The indexing begins at zero, with the first element having index 0, the second having index 1, and so on.

Syntax: 

var array_name[:datatype];        //declaration 

array_name = [val1,val2,valn..]   //initialization

Example:

let values: number[] = [];

values[0] = 10;

values[1] = 20;

values[2] = 30;

excerpt.rendered: A collection of values of the same data type is called an array. It’s a kind that’s been defined by the user. To store values of the same kind, you use arrays. Arrays are collections of values that are ordered and indexed. The indexing begins at zero, with the first element having index 0, the second having […]

title.rendered: List the Applications of TypeScript

content.rendered:
• Both client-side and server-side JavaScript applications can be built with TypeScript.
  • TypeScript is used to create both client-side and server-side JavaScript applications.
  • Because TypeScript adds more functionality and provides errors directly in the code, it can be used instead of JavaScript.
  • TypeScript is a programming language that is used to create large-scale enterprise systems.

excerpt.rendered: Both client-side and server-side JavaScript applications can be built with TypeScript. TypeScript is used to create both client-side and server-side JavaScript applications. Because TypeScript adds more functionality and provides errors directly in the code, it can be used instead of JavaScript. TypeScript is a programming language that is used to create large-scale enterprise systems.

title.rendered: List the Advantages of TypeScript

content.rendered:
• Problems are highlighted throughout development and at compilation time.
  • Typescript can be run in any browser or JavaScript engine.
  • A namespace notion is created by declaring a module.
  • IntelliSense is a TypeScript feature that provides active hints as you type.
  • Strongly typed or static typing is supported. The advantage of TypeScript is that it is strictly typed or allows for static typing. Because of static typing, it may confirm type correctness at compilation time.

excerpt.rendered: Problems are highlighted throughout development and at compilation time. Typescript can be run in any browser or JavaScript engine. A namespace notion is created by declaring a module. IntelliSense is a TypeScript feature that provides active hints as you type. Strongly typed or static typing is supported. The advantage of TypeScript is that it is […]

title.rendered: Explain Loops in Typescript

content.rendered:
A loop statement allows to repeat the execution of a statement or a series of statements. To handle looping requirements, TypeScript provides a variety of loops.

  • For Loop

The for loop is a definite loop implementation. A definite loop is defined as a loop with a fixed number of iterations.

  • While Loop

When the condition supplied evaluates to true, the while loop executes the instructions.

  • Do..While Loop

The do…while loop is identical to the while loop, except that the condition isn’t evaluated the first time the loop runs.

excerpt.rendered: A loop statement allows to repeat the execution of a statement or a series of statements. To handle looping requirements, TypeScript provides a variety of loops. For Loop The for loop is a definite loop implementation. A definite loop is defined as a loop with a fixed number of iterations. While Loop When the condition […]

title.rendered: Explain the features of Arrays in TypeScript

content.rendered:
• An array declaration allocates memory blocks in a sequential order.
  • Arrays are immutable. This means that once an array is created, it cannot be resized.
  • An array element is represented by each memory block.
  • The subscript/index of an array element is a unique number that identifies the element.
  • Arrays, like variables, should be declared before being used. Declare an array with the var keyword.
  • The term “array initialization” refers to the process of filling an array with elements.
  • The values of array elements can be updated or modified, but they cannot be erased.

excerpt.rendered: An array declaration allocates memory blocks in a sequential order. Arrays are immutable. This means that once an array is created, it cannot be resized. An array element is represented by each memory block. The subscript/index of an array element is a unique number that identifies the element. Arrays, like variables, should be declared before […]

title.rendered: Name the access modifiers supported in TypeScript.

content.rendered:
The access modifiers supported by TypeScript are:

  • Protected- All child classes and members have access to them, but the instance does not.
  • Private- Only members have access
  • Public- Members, child classes, and instances of the class have access to the public modifier.

excerpt.rendered: The access modifiers supported by TypeScript are: Protected- All child classes and members have access to them, but the instance does not. Private- Only members have access Public- Members, child classes, and instances of the class have access to the public modifier.

title.rendered: How to declare a variable in TypeScript?

content.rendered:
• Let and const are the two methods to declare variables.
  • Alphabets and numeric digits can both be used in variable names.
  • Except for the underscore (_) and the dollar ($) sign, they cannot contain spaces or special characters.
  • A digit can’t be the first character in a variable name.

let var a=10;

 or

function f() {

  var message = “Hello, world!”;

  return message;

}

excerpt.rendered: Let and const are the two methods to declare variables. Alphabets and numeric digits can both be used in variable names. Except for the underscore (_) and the dollar ($) sign, they cannot contain spaces or special characters. A digit can’t be the first character in a variable name. let var a=10;  or function f() […]

title.rendered: List the disadvantages of TypeScript

content.rendered:
• It takes a long time to compile TypeScript code.
  • Abstract classes are not supported in TypeScript.
  • Converting TypeScript to JavaScript requires an additional compilation step.
  • Its type scheme is extremely complicated.

excerpt.rendered: It takes a long time to compile TypeScript code. Abstract classes are not supported in TypeScript. Converting TypeScript to JavaScript requires an additional compilation step. Its type scheme is extremely complicated.

title.rendered: What is the use of the tsconfig.json file?

content.rendered: The tsconfig.json file is a JSON format file where you may specify several options to inform the compiler how to compile a project. The presence of this file in the directory implies that it is the TypeScript project root.

excerpt.rendered: The tsconfig.json file is a JSON format file where you may specify several options to inform the compiler how to compile a project. The presence of this file in the directory implies that it is the TypeScript project root.

title.rendered: What is meant by contextual typing?

content.rendered: When one side of the equation has type but the other does not, the TypeScript compiler determines the form. You can skip typing on the right side because TypeScript will figure it out for you. This reduces the amount of time spent typing code.

excerpt.rendered: When one side of the equation has type but the other does not, the TypeScript compiler determines the form. You can skip typing on the right side because TypeScript will figure it out for you. This reduces the amount of time spent typing code.

title.rendered: What is JSX?

content.rendered:
It’s a syntax that’s similar to XML and can be embedded. It must be converted into TypeScript that is valid. The JSX file with the.tsx extension is used.

JSX has an XML-like syntax that can be embedded. It is intended to be turned into legitimate JavaScript, though the semantics of that transformation will vary depending on the implementation. TypeScript allows you to embed JSX, type verify it, and compile it to JavaScript immediately.

excerpt.rendered: It’s a syntax that’s similar to XML and can be embedded. It must be converted into TypeScript that is valid. The JSX file with the.tsx extension is used. JSX has an XML-like syntax that can be embedded. It is intended to be turned into legitimate JavaScript, though the semantics of that transformation will vary depending […]

title.rendered: Define static typing

content.rendered: Static typing refers to a compiler that has recognisable variables, arguments, and object members at compile time. This aids in the early detection of faults.

excerpt.rendered: Static typing refers to a compiler that has recognisable variables, arguments, and object members at compile time. This aids in the early detection of faults.

title.rendered: What are import and export keywords in TypeScript?

content.rendered:
• Import keyword is used to export declaration. Example: export * from module
  • Any variable, function, or type alias can be exported with the export keyword

excerpt.rendered: Import keyword is used to export declaration. Example: export * from module Any variable, function, or type alias can be exported with the export keyword

title.rendered: Can TypeScript be used for the backend?

content.rendered: By combining TypeScript with Node.js, backend applications can benefit from the added security that the language provides.

excerpt.rendered: By combining TypeScript with Node.js, backend applications can benefit from the added security that the language provides.

title.rendered: How will you check if a variable is null or undefined in TypeScript?

content.rendered: if(value) return true if value is not null, undefined, empty, false, 0 or NaN.

excerpt.rendered: if(value) return true if value is not null, undefined, empty, false, 0 or NaN.

title.rendered: What are getters/setters?

content.rendered: Getters and setters prevent access to an object’s members.They allow you to have more precise control over how a member interacts with each object. A getter method starts with keyword ‘get’ and setter method starts with keyword ‘set’

excerpt.rendered: Getters and setters prevent access to an object’s members.They allow you to have more precise control over how a member interacts with each object. A getter method starts with keyword ‘get’ and setter method starts with keyword ‘set’

title.rendered: How can a class constant be implemented in TypeScript?

content.rendered: Class properties cannot be declared with the const keyword. The keyword ‘const’ cannot be used in a class member.

excerpt.rendered: Class properties cannot be declared with the const keyword. The keyword ‘const’ cannot be used in a class member.

title.rendered: What is the Declare Keyword in TypeScript?

content.rendered: Since JavaScript lacks a TypeScript declaration, the declare keyword is used to include it in a TypeScript file without causing a compilation issue. Ambient methods and declarations use the term to define a variable that already exists.

excerpt.rendered: Since JavaScript lacks a TypeScript declaration, the declare keyword is used to include it in a TypeScript file without causing a compilation issue. Ambient methods and declarations use the term to define a variable that already exists.

title.rendered: What is an Interface with reference to TypeScript?

content.rendered: The interface specifies the syntax that classes must use. All of the members of an interface are implemented by a class that implements it. It’s possible to refer to it, but not to use it. A type-checking interface is used by the TypeScript compiler.

excerpt.rendered: The interface specifies the syntax that classes must use. All of the members of an interface are implemented by a class that implements it. It’s possible to refer to it, but not to use it. A type-checking interface is used by the TypeScript compiler.
